bio: I have postgrad degrees in Professional Marketing [UNSW], Gastronomy [Uni Adelaide] Writing [UTS] and dozens of post-trade quals in food, cooking etc. I am also a PermaCulture teacher and have the PDC qual. I am very active in Dirt Club at UTS where I manage the compost tea bank and the wormfarms. I have qualified as a judge in the areas of olive oil, cheese and honey. I have started judging hive products at the RAS and was the sole judge honey & hive products for the Colonel Pulling Trophy for the amateur beekeeping clubs of NSW. I present regularly at conferences here and overseas on cookbooks, food marketing, functional foods, etc

In my spare time I am making a genius game of resemblance inspired by @hipbonegamer and Hesse's Magister Ludi / glass bead game.

bio: Job: Lecturer in Digital Humanities, Centre for Digital Humanities Research, Australian National University. Interests: Text mining, machine learning, and other data-driven approaches to literary-historical research. Background: French literary, intellectual, and book history (1750-1950).

bio: Jessica is currently working on client business innovation at immersive technology startup iSee. Her background is in both higher education and marketing information and measurement leading the the practical implication of new technology solutions.

bio: I am a historical archaeologist and is currently the FAIMS (www.fedarch.org) Research Fellow in the Archaeology Program at La Trobe University. I specialise in urban assemblage analysis and material-culture studies, and have designed customised relational databases to store archaeological and historical data for the ‘Exploring the Archaeology of the Modern City’ project (www.latrobe.edu.au/amc). I have collaborated with Victorian eResearch Strategic Initiative (VeRSI) and the La Trobe eResearch Office on the Australian Historical Archaeological Database (AHAD, www.ahad.edu.au), funded by the Australian National Data Service (ANDS). I have published several papers and reports on urban archaeology, consumption studies, artefact cataloguing and database design.
name: Penny Crook
title: Research Fellow

bio: I am a newly appointed research assistant working in the humanities and I also enjoy writing as my creative outlet at home.
name: Jenny Noble

bio: I have been in my current role of University Faculty Librarian for Humanities at Curtin University in Perth for one year, but have worked at Curtin library in various positions for almost ten years. I am interested in how researchers can use new technologies to make themselves and their work more visible, enabling their data to be accessed in more relevant formats than traditional methods, which often don’t work well for humanities scholars. I am also interested in how we can incorporate Digital Humanities so that Universities recognise research outputs in those formats which do not necessarily fit with traditional outputs.
name: Marilyn Coen
title: Faculty Librarian

bio: Mitchell Whitelaw is an academic, writer and practitioner with interests in new media art and culture, especially generative systems, data-aesthetics, and digital cultural collections. His work has appeared in journals including Leonardo, Digital Creativity, Fibreculture, and Senses and Society. His current work spans materiality, data and culture, with a practical focus on creating “generous interfaces” for digital heritage. He has worked with institutions including the State Library of NSW, the National Archives, and the National Gallery of Australia, developing innovative interfaces to their digital collections. Mitchell is currently an Associate Professor in the Faculty of Arts and Design at the University of Canberra, where he leads the Digital Treasures program in the Centre for Creative and Cultural Research.
name: Mitchell Whitelaw

tags.content: Centre for Creative and Cultural Research

title: Associate Professor

In doing so I discovered an unusual affinity with javascript, which has since lead to job titles including the words "interface", "designer" and "developer" in no particular order. I've developed web applications for ACT and Federal Government and currently as a freelancer I contribute to open source projects Sakai and ArchivesSpace.

bio: Following a 30-year career in IT spanning enterprise systems management, software architecture and development, industry training, and a high-tech start-up, I returned to university to study community informatics and qualified as a librarian. I then went on to complete my Master of Business information Systems (Honours) degree while also teaching at the university. My master's thesis took a design-science approach to investigating archival systems interoperability and identified a number of technological and social barriers to equitable and consistent community access to institutional archives. I am now a doctoral candidate, concerned with investigating these barriers. My research comprises theoretical as well as design-science/action-research investigations of systems interoperability; conceptual modelling in archival informatics; metadata standards-setting; and organisational/social factors in archival systems design and implementation.
name: Greg Rolan
title: PhD Candidate

bio: Digital services coordinator and reference librarian at NLA. Passionate information hunter-gatherer.

bio: I was born and grew up in Italy; took an Italian Doctorate in Physics cum laude; left Italy and worked in IT and telecommunication in Germany, Australia, Switzerland, and France; learnt German and French; aquired the Australian citizenship; published scientific/technical papers and some Science Fiction stories; currently 2/3 through a PhD with a creative thesis in Communication at the University of Canberra.
name: Giulio Zambon
title: Graduate student

bio: I am halfway through my PhD developing a new methodology for working with theatre archives, making them accessible online and researching user interaction. After many years as an arts worker in theatre, music and dance I became frustrated at how proper documentation remains neglected and underutilised, to the detriment of our cultural heritage.
institution: ANU Centre for Digital Humanities Research
name: Gavin Findlay
title: PhD Candidate

bio: Somaya Langley has a background in the arts, sound, media, broadcast, festivals, archives, libraries digital collecting and digital preservation. She has worked for ABC Classic FM, the Australian Music Centre, as the Curator of Networked Media for the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia and is currently working for the National Library of Australia. She has also undertaken consultancy work for the Australia Council for the Arts to research and deliver the Archives in the Digital Era Scoping Study Report. Somaya was one of two Creative Co-Directors/Co-Producers of the 2008 and 2009 Electrofringe festivals, Australia’s festival of electronic arts and culture and was Production Manager of the International Society of Contemporary Music World New Music Days festival in 2010. In 2009 she was Co-Curator of Transit Lounge, a partner project of Berlin’s transmediale festival. She loves working at the nexus between the arts, culture, society and technology.
name: Somaya Langley

Washington, in management and economics, now wants to engage in historical inquiry concerning lives of venturing whalers, women, merchants, adventurers, seamen ... even a convict or two and a horse arriving illegally..

title: Graduate Student

bio: Junran Lei has been involved in a number of system development projects in Humanities research. She developed AUSTLANG, an Australian Indigenous language database with GIS mapping features, OZBIB, a linguistic bibliography database, i‐Dig, a Fedora based search engine for harvested collections and a semantic web for museum prototype system. She worked as Researcher to investigate the development of an open source archival repository and preservation system for UNESCO. She is currently working on OCCAMS, an online cultural collection analysis and management system at the Centre for Digital Humanities Research, Australian National University.
name: Junran Lei

bio: Family History Researcher & Student

title: Researcher

bio: I joined the National Library of Australia in February 2014 as the Manager eResources Consortium. The Consortium is a National & State Libraries Australasia (NSLA) project that secures access to commercial electronic information resources for its members. The Consortium aims to simplify licensing arrangements, improve cost benefits for member libraries, and to explore opportunities for making eResources more widely available to all Australians, regardless of where they live. I returned to Australian in 2010 after spending ten years working in Fiji where I was active in library development, advocacy and access to information in the Pacific.
name: Libby Cass
title: Manager eResources Consortium

bio: Tilly Hinton is exploring the historical interactions of people with highly ubanised rivers in Los Angeles and Sydney, through a PhD in environmental history at the University of Technology, Sydney. She has led and contributed to a range of initiatives focused on education, the environment and community development, including managing the GREENhouse at Woodford Folk Festival. In her spare time she consults to the higher education sector (on research dissemination and impact optimisation for educational research), cooks, takes photos, and writes.
name: Tilly Hinton
title: Graduate Student

bio: A dabbler in digital art, I'm currently studying how we can navigate DCH collections by emotion.

title: Graduate student

bio: I'm currently working on the Collection Discoverability program at the National Gallery of Australia. As Collection Systems Officer, Discoverability, my role is to facilitate the inclusion of contextual data into the Collection Management System in support the wider Collection Discoverability Project aims of improving the ability for NGA visitors to find, browse, interpret and respond to works of art according to their own needs and interests. I have previous workplace experience within the Arts and Cultural and Tertiary sectors in a variety of roles with Queensland Art Gallery and Gallery of Modern (Brisbane), James Cook University (Townsville) and Perc Tucker Regional Gallery (Townsville). I am also currently engaged in Higher Degree research in the Humanities field in a part-time capacity through James Cook University. My research centers around an investigation and articulation of the cultural constructs that contemporary Australian artists who use collection practices within their artistic practice engage with.
name: Renée Joyce
title: Collection Systems Officer, Discoverability

bio: I'm an former National Library worker catching up on what's been happening with Trove and other such interactive technologies since I left the Library a couple of years ago. I'm now embarking on a new adventure - working with volunteer Wikipedians who are contributing to the history of the Australian Paralympic movement.
name: Elizabeth Watt
title: History Project Volunteer CoordinatorrResearch

bio: I am currently a Reader in Archaeology and Ancient History at the University of Leicester. I grew up on a sheep farm in North Canterbury, New Zealand. My undergraduate degree was in Pure Mathematics from the University of Canterbury (New Zealand), and my MA Prelim, MA Honours, and PhD in Archaeology from the University of Sydney. I have previously taught archaeology and ancient history at the University of Sydney, the Australian National University, and the University of Sheffield. I have held an Australian Research Council Postdoctoral Fellow and a U2000 Research Fellow at Sydney University, and an Australian Research Council Queen Elizabeth II Fellow at the Australian National University. I also held an Australian Bicentennial fellowship in the Faculty of Classics, University of Cambridge, and a visiting fellowship at St John's College, University of Durham. I became a Reader in Archaeology at the Australian National University in 2005. I am a Fellow of the Society of Antiquaries and an Honorary Fellow of the Australian Academy of Humanities. From September to December 2014 I am a Harold White Fellow at the National Library of Australia.
name: Penelope Allison

tags.content: Research Council Queen Elizabeth II Fellow
Fellow of the Society of Antiquaries

bio: I am the Senior Lecturer in Digital Humanities at the University of Western Sydney. My background is primarily in linguistics, where my main research interest is how languages change, vary, and interact with each other. I have worked on a variety of database and mapping projects, as well as recently becoming involved in modelling and simulation. I build robots in my spare time.
name: Rachel Hendery

bio: I love sharing Trove's riches with the world.
name: Catriona Bryce
title: Trove Support

bio: I am a reformed accountant who moved into public relations then morphed into historical research. I am interested in the rise of the secular in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries and the tension between the secular and religious during this period. Currently I'm analysing WWI soldiers' diaries using the transcriptions of the diaries held by the State Library of NSW for a history I am writing about the personal beliefs of soldiers while on the front. The engine of my research is a simple Python program I have written to search the diaries for certain keywords. You can read more about this project on my blog, Stumbling Through the Past. In my digital humanities blog, Stumbling Through the Future I give simple step by step explanations of how to use some useful tools. Most recently I did a series of posts on getting started with the Trove API. My first THATCamp was a great one - Canberra 2011 (see my post. In 2013 I helped to organise a THATCamp connected with the annual conference of the Australian Historical Association in Wollongong - THATCamp #OzHA2013 and I attended THATCamp in Sydney last year.
name: perkinsy

bio: I am currently employed as a Communications and Outreach Officer for the ARC Centre of Excellence for the Dynamics of Language. My own research explores language, literacy and social organisation in Asia and Australia. I am currently building a digital archive for the literature of the utopian Eskaya community of the southern Philippines and developing unicode-enabled fonts for the Eskaya script among other Messianic alphabets of the region, allowing for better analysis of their associated literary corpora.
institution: ARC Centre of Excellence for the Dynamics of Language
name: Piers Kelly
title: Communications and Outreach Coordinator

bio: PhD student in UC's Digital Treasures program. Background in the cultural heritage sector.

bio: I'm a digital historian, web developer and cultural data hacker who's been developing online resources relating to archives, museums and history since 1993. I've written on weather, progress and the atomic age, and developed resources including Bright Sparcs, Mapping our Anzacs and QueryPic. I'm currently the Manager of Trove at the National Library of Australia, as well as being an Adjunct Associate Professor in the Centre for Creative and Cultural Research at the University of Canberra. I was one of the organisers of THATCamp Canberra in 2010 and 2011.
name: Tim Sherratt

bio: Steve is one of those scary computer-literate environmental scientists who would have taken over the world, if their energies hadn't been channelled into other areas such as IT support. His only interest is improving the IT literacy of Fenner School staff and students (this seems to be working, because over the past year he found some time for other things like virtualising the remaining Fenner School IT server infrastructure, and replacing the Fenner School's print-quota-ing system). And making computers do what he expects... Amongst his interests are ensuring people learn how to use their computers properly; forcing said computers into behaving themselves; making sensible use of multi-media systems; further simplifying the administration of the Fenner School computer servers; occasionally making the acquaintance of a thesaurus; running around the house cleaning up after the child; paraphrasing Monty Python where-ever it seems appropriate; boldly splitting infinitives where no-one has split them before; recycling most of his BIO from an old Fenner School yearbook entry; and writing about himself somewhat facetiously in the third-person.
institution: Fenner School of Environment & Society, Australian National University
name: Steve Leahy
title: Programmer/Multi-media Services

bio: Angela is a Canadian Brit who is interested in all things digital. She has a background in education, e-Learning, and champions the democratising of education, additive manufacturing and the Slow Movement. She is a confirmed MOOC-a-holic. She moved to Canberra from London in 2013 with her husband and children, but originally hails from a small town in rural Alberta called Rocky Mountain House. In her spare time she loves camping, kayaking, snorkelling, and MOOCing with Coursera, edX, FutureLearn and NovoEd. Since meeting her husband while working in northern Japan 18 years ago, she’s lived in The UK, Romania, and in Tbilisi, Georgia working in various roles including as an e-Learning policy advisor, web designer and manager, User Experience Consultant, teacher trainer, lecturer, education manager, teacher trainer, teacher and as a jewellery designer & maker. She has an MA in TEFL (Teaching English as a Foreign Language) and a Bachelor of Education with specializations in Inter-Cultural Communication and e-Learning. In 2007, Angela was selected as one of four diamond studies participants in the DTC (Diamond Trading Company formerly known as De Beers) Diamond Course in London. She also holds qualifications in silver & gold jewellery making, enamelling, flower-arranging and diamond studies.
name: Angela Richmond-Fuller
title: UX Consulting

My research sits within the Digital Treasures program where we focus on the development of generous interfaces for digital cultural collections. She is currently the Executive Officer of the Pacific Manuscripts Bureau, based at the Australian National University.
